results.title: Bird Watcher's Hide
results.brief_description: A young boy is introduced to bird watching by an experienced watcher. On the Scottish moors he learns how to select a bird, find the nest, construct the hide and patiently move it closer without disturbing the bird, until he is able to view intimately the bird’s habits. No other credits available.

results.title: Bird sanctuary
results.brief_description: The hatching and rearing of young seabirds in the Farne Islands off the coast of Britain. Such well-known birds as the kittiwakes, the guillemots, the cormorants, the puffins, the terns, the elderducks and the lesser known black-backed gulls are observed.

results.title: A Bird of prey: the red-tailed hawk
results.creator_credit: Edward C. Harris and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: Examines the life cycle of a red-tailed hawk. Shows the physical qualities that help the hawk to survive. Establishes the importance of the red-tailed hawk in maintaining ecological balance. Conveys the reasons for the hawk’s decline in numbers.

results.title: Biography of the unborn
results.creator_credit: Milan Herzog and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: Traces the development of the human foetus from conception to birth. Charts, animated drawings, x-rays and photomicrographs show the process of fertilization, the division of cells, the nourishment of the embryo, the development of internal organs, and the nervous system, and other phases of development which take place during the gestation period.

results.title: The Biography of the motion picture camera
results.creator_credit: Roger Leenhardt and Les Films du Compas
results.brief_description: The story of the motion picture camera, carries further the history of the antecedents of cinema, showing how the development of the cinema arose out of scientists desire to analyse movement, in order to study the movements of animals and birds. The first man to undertake a scientific study of movement was Marey, a french physician; his experiments were extended by Edward Muybridge, a San Francisco photographer, who settled a trans-Atlantic argument about the way a horse gallops by using a battery of 24 cameras to photograph its movements. The problem then remained of creating one camera capable of doing the job of these 24. Marey, among others, achieved this by inventing the chronophotograph; Edison in America made a further advance by introducing celluloid film in place of photographic plates. Edison also invented a projector, which allowed only one person to view the film; it was Louis Lumiere in France who invented the first successful commercial projector which enabled him to show motion picture films to a fairly large audience. The Lumiere brothers began to make films about every-day events which at the time proved sensational.

results.title: Bing bang boom
results.creator_credit: Joan Henson, Joseph Koenig and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A novel way of discovering music without instruments, in a Grade 7 classroom. Innovator and Toronto composer R. Murray Shafer is teacher for a day. His purpose is to show children that music is more than painfully learned notes and scales. He has the class listen to every sound around them and then harmonize and orchestrate what they hear - their voices, hands, feet - into a rhythmic musical pattern. The result is a hit, and a convincing illustration that children learn best when it’s from the inside out. Awards: American Film Festival; Sydney.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Joan Henson, Joseph Koenig and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Binary bit patterns
results.creator_credit: Michael Whitney, Information International and Motion Graphics and Pyramid Films
results.brief_description: This film puts a musical backing to a kaleidoscope of regular and abstract patterns based on geometric computer forms. Rapid movement of these ever-changing images is created with variations in colour and visual effect. Suitable for secondary years 7-12.

results.title: Bim
results.creator_credit: Albert Lamorisse, Georges Derocles and L'Ecran des Jeunes
results.brief_description: Bim is the first achievement of director, Albert Lamorisse and, as in the case of Crin Blanc and his latest release ‘The Red Balloon’, he has made a delightful film. Photographed in Algiers, it tells of the adventures of a donkey and his youthful, affectionate owner. Lamorisse is one of those film makers who have a camera eye, that is the gift of pointing the camera lens to obtain pictures of infinite expressiveness. The most distinguished director in this field is Robert Flaherty. The story is that long ago in a far off Eastern Island, it was the custom for each child to have a baby donkey as a pet. One day the son of the Prince was riding haughtily through the streets when he took a fancy to Bim, the donkey belonging to a poor boy called Abdallah. The guards kidnapped Bim, who found himself a prisoner, condemned to death for eating the Great Prince’s dinner, Bim was rescued by thieves who raided the island for animals. After a thrilling chase on land and sea, Abdallah and his friends managed to rescue Bim and all ended happily. Narrated by William Bledsoe.

results.title: Billy's helicopter ride
results.brief_description: Introduces the helicopter and its uses through the story of a young boy taking his first ride. Gives children an opportunity to experience second-hand what they might never experience themselves.

results.title: Bill Tilden's advanced tennis
results.creator_credit: Julian Peyser and New Official Films
results.brief_description: Bill Tilden narrates and demonstrates advanced techniques of tennis, including net game, foot work, smash, service and volley. Front, back, aside and overhead views permit study of his playing technique from a variety of angles.
